The role played by the concept of presence in validating the efficacy of a cybertherapy treatment: a literature review
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • SI: Cyberinterventions
  • Published: 07 January 2014

The role played by the concept of presence in validating the efficacy of a cybertherapy treatment: a literature review

  • Anna Spagnolli1,
  • Cheryl Campanella Bracken2 &
  • Valeria Orso1 

Virtual Reality volume 18, pages13–36(2014)Cite this article

  • 757 Accesses

  • 10 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

The present paper considers the existing research in cybertherapy, which is a psychological therapy carried out with the use of a mediated environment, and examines the way in which the users’ sense of presence in the mediated environment can be of relevance for the validation of the intervention. With this purpose, a collection of 41 papers reporting the measurement of presence in the context of a cybertherapy treatment has been identified and examined. The general relevance of presence in cybertherapy and the measurement techniques adopted in the studies collected here are described and discussed. The way in which presence corresponds to establishing internal validity, convergent or predictive validity and external validity of a treatment is examined. In conclusion, a checklist to apply when planning a validation study is proposed, to improve the way in which presence is used.

Validation in cybertherapy

Cybertherapy is a term used in clinical and health psychology to identify psychological therapy carried out with the use of a mediated environment, i.e., an environment supported by an information or communication technology such as computers, mobile phones, specific related devices (e.g., biosensors, headsets, and helmet) and even TV. The mediated environment supporting a cybertherapy treatment offers visual and other perceptual synthetic stimuli produced by the technology that (a) facilitate the achievement of a target psychological condition such as distraction, relaxation or proficiency in cognitive tasks and/or (b) supports and motivates performance, as in rehabilitative exercises. Although on-line counseling has been also considered as cybertherapy [e.g., (Botella et al. 2009)], we will not consider here those mediated environments that just provide a venue where patient and therapist can talk, such as email or Internet fora. We will only consider those mediated environments that embed some clinical treatment, whether they are specifically designed for the treatment or adaptations to clinical purposes of existing commercial applications, like in (Bouchard et al. 2008) where a videogame desert-like scenario was adapted for a snake-phobia treatment. Most commonly, cybertherapy is used to treat psychological conditions related to disorders such as anxiety disorders, eating disorders, autism, and phobias; to treat substance abuse and addiction; to reduce the pain and discomfort perceived during unpleasant medical treatments; to manage stress; and to administer exercises for cognitive rehabilitation (e.g., memory or attention training for elderly people; Wiederhold and Wiederhold 2004; Scozzari and Gamberini 2011). Results of this treatment mode are comparable with those obtained in counseling or therapy protocols that are not supported by a mediated environment (e.g., Malloy and Milling 2010; Powers and Emmelkamp 2008), with some additional advantages that may make cybertherapy a preferable option. The most obvious advantage is that the mediated environment allows patients to experience situations, to display stimuli or to provide feedback of the patient’s action that in vivo would be not controllable (e.g., crowd behavior), not feasible (e.g., scenario variation to improve transfer of skills) or unavailable [e.g., an iced world mitigating pain during medical treatment from severe burning (Wiederhold and Wiederhold 2004)]. In addition, the use of a mediated environment minimizes implementation failures, which primarily occur as a consequence of straying from the planned intervention procedure (Dusenbury et al. 2003) because, to some extent, a mediated environment embeds the administration manual: standard task instructions and explanations, organization of stimuli into subsequent treatment steps, and setting options for personalized treatment. Finally, the use of information and communication technology in delivering a psychological therapy allows treatment to reach people in critical conditions, for instance people with disabilities or living in remote regions, improve persistency, ubiquity, anonymity, multimodality of an intervention, as well as the ease with which data can be stored, accessed, and manipulated (Botella et al. 2009; Fogg 2003). It is worth specifying that cybertherapy is not necessarily a self-administered therapy: in general, the presence of a therapist is always recommended in the protocol, and the protocol also includes other treatment modes in addition to the virtual treatment.

Like any clinical treatment, a cybertherapy treatment needs to be validated, namely, it must be ascertained that it can achieve its planned objectives. The concept of validation has been deeply elaborated in psychology and in the social sciences, where a measurement tool, an experiment or a treatment are considered valid when they are able to do what they intend to do (Brewer 2000; Campbell 1987; Carmines and Zeller 1979). The process of ascertaining their validity, or validation, can be used to assess the efficacy of their design and is called internal validity (Brewer 2000; Campbell 1987; Carmines and Zeller 1979). Efficacy assessment in case of a clinical treatment is the ‘systematic and scientific evaluation of whether a treatment works’ ‘as compared to an alternative intervention or with no treatment, in a controlled clinical context’ [(Alsina-Jurnet and Gutièrrez-Maldonado 2010), p. 1053]. Two specific forms of internal validity most often identified are criterion and content validity: The former demonstrates that a valid criterion correlates with the outcomes of the object of validation in the present or in the future (concurrent or predictive validity); the latter ensures that the object of validation properly and comprehensively represents the domain it intends to cover. Besides strictly evaluating the short term, direct outcomes of a treatment, internal validation also includes considering long-term outcomes, indirect consequences and side effects, patients’ subjective satisfaction and the fact that different parties in the intervention can have different goals.

In addition to internal validity, a measurement tool/experiment/treatment can be validated to demonstrate construct validity, namely establishing the relationship on a theoretical basis between the outcomes of the object of validation and other concept(s) that can be measured. The measurement tool/experiment/treatment can be validated externally, for their generalizability across persons, times and settings (Campbell 1987). In case of a clinical psychological treatment, generalizability assessment is combined with feasibility assessment (e.g., its costs, acceptability, training of administering personnel and infrastructure) in order to determine its clinical utility (Alsina-Jurnet and Gutièrrez-Maldonado 2010). Finally, in addition to being empirically supported, a clinical treatment in psychology needs to be integrated with clinical expertise in the context of patient characteristics, culture, and preferences (APA Presidential Task Force on Evidence-Based Practice 2006).

In case of cybertherapy, hardware and software are combined to achieve to the final therapeutic goals. We are not referring here to the verification (Pegden et al. 1995) of the functioning of the technology supporting cybertherapy or to the evaluation of the usability of the tool, which is instrumental to efficacy but cannot generate healing effects per se; we refer to the quality of the experience of this world, which is supposed to facilitate the clinical outcome. The hardware shapes the way in which this content is experienced, whether in isolation from the surrounding or merged with them and whether involving the body in a natural interaction with the environment or mediating the interaction with input devices. The software content embeds and makes concrete abstract sceneries, imagined situations, feared objects, subjective symbols and meanings. We then argue that the mediated environment concurs with internal validity of the treatment in addition to the protocol, and therefore, they are part of the internal validation before being a matter of generalizability to different platforms and settings. The way in which the mediated experience is intended to assist the clinical outcome must then be defined and assessed as part of an overall, faceted validation of the cybertherapy treatment. One dimension of the mediated experience is the sense of being in the mediated environment, or presence, and the use of this concept in the validation of cybertherapy treatment is the topic of this review.

In this paper, we have collected and analyzed cybertherapy works published through 2011 where assessing the presence was described by the authors as a substantial aspect of the study. The paper is organized as follows: Sect. 1.1 describes the search and final sample; Sect. 2 briefly illustrates the notion of presence and its relevance to cybertherapy and offers a table with the detailed analysis of each paper included in our collection; Sect. 3 describes the role attributed to presence in the studies reviewed; Sect. 4 examines how presence is measured in this literature; Sect. 5 summarizes the points made in the paper and proposes some final recommendations for future cybertherapy efforts.

Review method

The creation of the sample occurred in two steps. First, we searched two scientific databases (i.e., PsycInfo and ACM Digital Library), looking for publications in English published until 2011 with the terms presence AND therapy/treatment in their title, abstract or keywords with no constraints on the publication year. When the query was for searching the abstract, filters were applied to limit the results (e.g., human factors engineering; communication systems; engineering and environmental psychology). This process returned 211 items including duplicates. In parallel, an examination of several scientific outlets that are most devoted to cover the two topics was done, always checking for papers treating presence and cybertherapy together. These outlets are the proceedings of ‘The Annual International Workshop on Presence’; the journals ‘Presence: Teleoperators and Virtual Environments,’ ‘Cyberpsychology, Behavior and Social Networking’ formerly ‘Cyberpsychology and Behavior,’ the ‘Annual Review of CyberTherapy and Telemedicine,’ the ‘Journal of CyberTherapy and Rehabilitation’ and ‘PsychNology Journal’ which devoted several special issues to presence or cybertherapy. This resulted in an additional 22 items.

After discarding duplicates, works that turned out to be unrelated (e.g., works on ‘therapeutic presence,’ ‘simulated presence therapy’ or using the term ‘presence’ in a generic way as in ‘the presence of a disease’), works that did not carry out any empirical assessment of presence, or that announced to use a presence measurement tool but did not report the results of such measurement, 41 papers remained. A complete list of the papers is provided in Table 1.

The papers were then examined to find the specific psychological disorder or sufferance addressed (‘disease’); the nature of the mediated environment through which the cybertherapy was delivered (‘mediated environment’); the role played by presence in the study (‘role of presence’); the measures of presence adopted in the study (‘measure of presence’) and the results collected regarding presence (‘findings’). In this way, we attempted to represent the diverse purposes with which presence is used in cybertherapy literature and the way in which each usage of the notion of presence represent a way to validate cybertherapy.

The relevance of the ‘sense of being there’ for cybertherapy

Before delving into more specific, theoretically driven definitions (see Sect. 4), presence can be simply defined as the ‘sense of being there,’ namely the subjective experience of being in a mediated environment (Witmer and Singer 1998). The concept is then broken down in several sub-dimensions, specifically, spatial presence, involvement, realness, social presence and reality judgment (see Table 2). It was first used in this sense by Reeves (Reeves 1991) and then adopted in domain of virtual reality; the construct of presence was used to test the effectiveness of virtual reality as an immersive system or a system where the synthetic stimuli produced by the technology replace the stimuli from the physical surrounding, at least in the domain of vision and acoustics. The concept of immersion was also related to virtual reality technology, and specifically to the extent to which the virtual environment saturated the users’ perception excluding the stimuli from the real world (Slater and Wilbur 1997). The concept of presence instead was related to the users’ experience of the virtual environment (Slater and Wilbur 1997) and referred to the extent to which the user actually felt present in the virtual environment generated by the technology. The assumption was that an effectively immersive system supports a sense of presence in the mediated environment, enticing the user away from the physical environment. Presence then provided a means to assess construct validity for immersive environments.

This initial formulation presupposes an opposition between mediated and physical environments, since the user’s presence in the virtual environment was supposed to be an alternative to his/her presence in the physical environment, in a model where the ideal virtual environment was a self-sufficient replacement of the real one. The appropriateness of conceptualizing presence within such an oppositional framework has been questioned in subsequent studies arguing that the user to some extent remains involved in the physical environment even during effective immersive sessions and that occasionally attending to events in the physical world—for instance to adjust the equipment—does not involve a dismissal of the involvement with the mediated one (e.g., Spagnolli and Gamberini 2002; Waterworth and Waterworth 2001). Kim and Biocca argue that ‘the user may be maintaining two separate but partial models of both the physical environment and virtual environment, so that he/she might feel present in the virtual environment, but not completely removed from the physical environment’ (Kim and Biocca 1997). In addition to theoretical reasons, the relaxation of the notion of presence in a mediated environment—from being conceived as the radically alternative of being present in the physical environment to being conceived as intermeshed with it—is also due to one further reason, namely, the increasing interest in mixed and augmented reality that have no pretense of saturating the users’ experience. An example of the benefits of immersion is discussed by (Bowman and McMahan 2007). This is especially true in cybertherapy, where aside from immersive virtual reality technology (e.g., head-mounted display or CAVES), there are non-immersive devices such as desktop PCs (Tichon and Banks 2006), TV screens for restorative films after stressful events (Sponselee et al. 2004), mobile phones to provide relaxation among commuters (Grassi et al. 2009) or to support physical exercise (Chittaro and Sioni 2012). Also, there are cybertherapy applications in which the physical environment continues to be conspicuous during the treatment—e.g., during painful medications or with the therapist intervening during the technologically mediated session from the ‘real’ world.

In all cases, whether using an immersive technology or not, cybertherapy is strictly connected with the concept of presence. Cybertherapy employs fictional scenes or synthetic stimuli, designed to induce a certain psychological state or keep the user well focused on the mediated experience during the treatment. While in other application (e.g., games, e-learning, scientific visualization, virtual prototyping) domains, the use of the mediated experience can represent an added value, but not a precondition to achieving the users’ goal (e.g., completing a game, learning a skill, understanding a scientific concept, drawing a prototype), in cybertherapy failing to design a mediated environment that provides a powerful experience can prevent the achievement of the intended outcome. Making the user feel present in the mediated environment or in the hybrid environment constituted of physical and digital stimuli remains crucial, and measuring presence is a way to assess the achievement of this goal. Researchers make the assumption that if the person feels highly present in the simulated world where the treatment is administered, then the symbols and events mobilized by the mediated environment in will be more deeply experienced by the patient with positive implications for the treatment. For this reason, assessing whether the patient feels present in the mediated world is part of the internal validation of the cybertherapy treatment (Sect. 4.1). In addition, since presence can be influenced in principle not only by characteristics of the communication technologies, such as interactivity (Steuer 1995), but also by the content presented [e.g., its realism (Bowman and McMahan 2007)], by the meaning that the environment has for its users (Spagnolli and Gamberini 2005) and by the personal characteristics of the users (e.g., locus of control Murray et al. 2007; Weibel et al. 2010), the sense of presence in the cybertherapy environment has also been studied with other purposes: to test the interdependence with other specific dimensions of the users’ experience during the treatment, e.g., anxiety or with the treatment outcome (Sect. 4.2) or to define the patient’s suitability to undergo a cybertherapy treatment altogether (Sect. 4.3). The former aspect pertains to construct validity of the treatment, the latter to its external validity (generalization across people).

Table 1 offers an overview of the studies collected for this paper and which utilized presence to validate cybertherapy. For each study, the following aspects are highlighted: The specific psychological disorder or sufferance that the treatment—once implemented in the mediated environment—is designed to address (‘disease’); the configuration of the virtual environment through which the cybertherapy is delivered (‘mediated environment’); the role as validation criterion played by presence in the study (‘role of presence’) and the way in which presence is assessed in the study (‘measure of presence’).

Presence and cybertherapy validation

In the literature reviewed in this study, three roles seem to be attributed to the concept of presence (marked with the letters A, B and C in the ‘Role of Presence’ column in Table 1). Presence is treated:

  1. a.

    as a construct that validates the efficacy of the mediated environment; feeling present in the mediated environment becomes a sub-goal of the cybertherapy experience, and establishing the internal validity of its design concurs with its intended outcomes;

  2. b.

    as a construct that might correlate with other relevant constructs capturing the users’ experience during/after the treatment, including the treatment outcome; if these correlations are found, subsequent studies can use presence measures as a criterion—among other—to establish the convergent or predictive validity of the treatment;

  3. c.

    as a dimension of the patients’ experience that is subject to individual variability due to specific characteristics of the users, such as their personality or the disease; identifying the factors affecting such variability concurs to determine the generalizability of the treatment across people and then the external validity of the treatment. Eligible patients can then be selected by assessing their ability to feel present in a virtual environment.

In the rest of this section, we will briefly discuss these three roles, illustrated in Fig. 1, and will utilize some examples from the studies from Table 1 to discuss them.

Presence as a sub-goal of the cybertherapy treatment

The simplest way in which presence can validate cybertherapy is by showing that patients experience a high sense of presence in the mediated environment during the treatment session. Sometimes, scholars use this approach preliminarily, before even implementing the full treatment in the VE, to select the final medium to adopt for the treatment. The work by Tichon and Banks (Tichon and Banks 2006) is a case in point; they compared a 150°, semi-curved screen with a 15-inch screen desktop PC as interface to experience a virtual environment staging visual and auditory hallucinations for treating schizophrenia. The results showed that both platforms were able to induce a high sense of presence, as was found by other studies they considered; curiously, self-reported tools focusing on observable presence determinant (e.g., control over the virtual environment) scored higher in the desktop application. Several other studies compare different cybertherapy platforms in terms of the sense of presence they are able to induce: augmented reality versus real environment (e.g., Juan et al. 2006); CAVE versus HMD presentation (e.g., Juan and Pérez 2009; Krijn et al. 2004); curved screen versus desktop PC (e.g., Tichon and Banks 2006); a projected video-capture VR platform (Gesture Extreme, GX VR) versus HMD versus a combination of the two (GX-HMD) (e.g., Rand et al. 2005); mediated environments varying the presence of video and audio narrative (e.g., Villani et al. 2007), the screen size (e.g., Sponselee et al. 2004) or the use of visible/invisible augmented reality markers (e.g., Juan and Joele 2011).

A cybertherapy application in which feeling present in the mediated space and removed away from the physical world is crucial is pain reduction. Schneider and Hood (2007) define the underlying process as distraction, conceiving the treatment as an ‘emotional-focus coping strategy because it diverts the focus of the attention away from the unpleasant stimuli by manipulating the environment’ (p. 40). Unfortunately, it is worth noting that many studies using cybertherapy as a distraction do not measure presence but just assume it occurs (Schneider and Hood 2007; Patterson et al. 2006).

There are some caveats in using the sense of presence as a way to validate the mediated environment and its interface, especially if the attempt is to compare different interfaces and discard the one inducing lower levels of presence. It might be the case that the interfaces do not differ in the sense of presence induced, even though from a strictly technical perspective the two environments differ in immersion. Advances in the studies of presence have shown that the feeling of being present does not depend on a pictorially realistic, saturating stimulation, and can in fact be experienced also with ‘poorer’ media or less immersive media such as books (Biocca 2003), television (Bracken 2005; Lombard et al. 2000) and iPods (Bracken et al. 2010). This is important for cybertherapy, not only because immersive equipment such as CAVES or curved screens might be expensive, but also because sometimes it is not convenient for practitioners. Conversely, similar environments can trigger very different responses according to the sample with which they are validated: presence and the feeling of inhabiting a certain space depends on the meaning afforded to this space by the user (Spagnolli and Gamberini 2005) and are then strictly connected with the emotional content of the experience (Alsina-Jurnet and Gutièrrez-Maldonado 2010). The emotional response can be higher in patients with certain diagnoses than in healthy users (e.g., Banos et al. 2004; Kim et al. 2008), and patients can feel more present in the mediated environment than healthy individuals [e.g., (Robillard et al. 2003) (see also Sect. 4.3)].

Relation with other relevant dimensions of the users’ psychological experience during/after the treatment

Several works in our sample tried to test the relation between the sense of presence and other dimensions of the users’ psychological experience during/after the treatment that are either relevant to the treatment at stake or that represent the desired outcome of that treatment; for treatment of phobias, anxiety is such a dimension; for treatment of substance addiction, craving can be a relevant dimension; for relaxation, stress is a relevant dimension; for rehabilitation, motivation and confidence can be relevant psychological dimensions. When these outcomes are driven by a theoretical elaboration, this relationship could provide a basis for construct validation of the treatment, namely for a validation where empirical measures operationalize construct that are first related theoretically.

One dimension experienced during the session is anxiety,Footnote 1 probably because several applications are directed to the treatment of phobias and other anxiety disorders. The relation between presence and anxiety is interesting because they seem to be interdependent. For example, Robillard et al. (2003) considered several phobias such as spiders, heights, or enclosed spaces and modified well-known game environments (e.g., Half-Life for arachnophobia and Unreal Tournament for acrophobia and claustrophobia) that are rich in these phobogenic elements. Participants affected by phobias were exposed for 20 min to phobogenic stimuli in an immersive virtual environment set-up and were compared with non-phobic participants receiving the same kind of stimuli. The authors found that both anxiety and presence were higher in phobic participants, in terms of immersive tendency (Witmer and Singer 1998) as well as in terms of perceived similarity of the VE with an equivalent natural environment experienced during the immersion (as measured by the Realism subscale of the presence questionnaire (PQ) (Witmer and Singer 1998), administered in a validated French adaptation). Furthermore, correlational and regression results showed that Anxiety and Presence were predictive of each other. The authors suggest that in phobic patients anxiety and presence affect each other synergically: anxiety can increase the sense of presence (because it compromises the users’ ability to recognize an illusion, or because it can be interpreted as a sign of realism of the virtual stimulus) and the sense of presence can increase anxiety (because it makes the phobogenic stimulus more real). Similar results were also obtained by Kim et al. (2008), who found that anxiety was correlated with immersive tendency. Another relevant dimension that has been connected to presence is craving in mediated environment for the treatment of addictions. For instance, Ferrer-Garcia et al. (2010) in the process of developing a virtual reality system to help smoking cessation, want to preliminarily validate the actual ability of some cues to trigger smoking craving, such as for example drinking coffee or waiting on the street. The rationale of the treatment, in fact, is that the environment must be able to gradually reduce, from session to session, the ability of certain cues to trigger smoking craving by way of exposure to craving stimuli and of learning ways to deal with such stimuli. The authors found a significant correlation between craving (measured through a visual analogical scale ranging from 1 to 100 administered before and after the immersive session) and presence levels (measured with the PQ).

The studies connecting presence with dimensions of the psychological experience after the immersion were more likely to connect presence with the treatment outcome. The readers can find several instances of studies with this approach in Table 1. One instance is represented by the study of Wald and Taylor in (2003); they tested a by driving phobia treatment consisting of 8 weekly sessions. It was based on a commercially available driving simulator experienced through a head-mounted display and allowing to select different scenarios (urban, highway, et) and weather conditions. In their exploratory study with five patients, the authors found that those participants who had higher presence scores in the virtual environment at the post-treatment assessment were also the ones who showed a clear improvement after treatment. Another instance is represented by the work by Quero et al. (2008), who extensively analyzed the relationship between treatment effectiveness and different components of presence (i.e., Emotional Involvement Reality Judgment and Presence, Interaction and External Correspondence, Influence of the Quality of the Software in the Reality Judgment and Presence, Software Ease of Use, Satisfaction with the Experience, and Attention) in an exposure therapy for a large span of psychological disorders (claustrophobia, flying phobia, eating disorders, acrophobia, panic disorder with agoraphobia, small animal phobia). The authors found that one component (i.e., Quality of the Software), predicted both pre- and post-treatment fear and avoidance and the scores in the specific questionnaire related to each patient’s problem; the emotional involvement component of presence predicted the scores in the specific questionnaire related to each patient’s problem.

It is worth noting that a lack of correlation between presence and a given psychological dimensions can depend on purely methodological reasons even though a relation between the two constructs exist. Presence scores might not vary as widely as other psychological dimensions; in fact, presence might reach a level beyond which it cannot further increase and this ceiling effect might undermine the bases of a correlation with other dimensions, as shown in (Bouchard et al. 2008). Therefore, the nature of expected relation between presence and other psychological dimensions must be carefully hypothesized by taking into account the nature and range of the variables operationalizing them.

Individual differences

In some studies included in our collection, presence is not related to the characteristics of the environment or to the emotions and feelings experienced during the session, but to the characteristics of the individual participant, which can be either personality characteristics or characteristics related to the specific disease. This approach characterizes the very idea of an immersive tendency, a notion that represents the fulcrum of a very famous measure of presence developed by Witmer and Singer (1998), and consisting of an individual predisposition to feel immersed or present in a virtual environment. This notion is probably connected with the idea that the presence is tantamount to an illusion; thus, not all individuals can ‘suspend their disbelief,’ or if you consider the presence to be a consequence of attention, not all individuals are able to ignore distracting stimuli (Laarni et al. 2004). Outside cybertherapy, Kober and Neuper (2012) recently analyzed several personality factors in order to identify which ones are better associated with presence measures in a generic virtual environment not designed for psychological treatment. They found that the factors that best corresponded with presence measures were absorption, mental imagination, perspective taking, and immersive tendencies. The factors relate directly to several studies reviewed here which measured test anxiety, spatial intelligence, verbal intelligence, personality and computer experience, attachment style, empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control.

Other studies in our collection consider how the specific disease of the patient can affect the intensity with which presence is experienced. In some cases, the disease leads to an intensification of the sense of presence. For instance, Alsina-Jurnet et al. (2010) found that a higher sense of presence in the VE emerged in the student group with high test anxiety and that this difference was higher in the emotional scenarios than in the neutral ones. Similarly, Robillard et al. (2003) found that phobic participants showed higher presence scores than non-phobic ones both in immersive tendency and in post-session assessment. In both cases, the reason for the higher sense of presence experienced by patients might be that elements of the VE were more meaningful to them. A similar explanation is used by Viciana-Abad et al. (2004) who compared specialists and non-specialists. They found that only specialists in critical care reported a high degree of presence in a medical emergency training simulator; non-specialists did so only in the environment that was stressful. The authors interpreted these results in the sense that being able to make full sense of some elements included in the VE is crucial to experiencing a high sense of presence in it.

In some other cases, the specific disease suffered by the patient decreases the ability to experience a sense of presence, at least for some indicators of presence: Lallart et al. (2009) found that the overall ratings to the IPQ were higher in the control group than in patients with schizophrenia. The control group felt the interaction with the VE more natural and realistic than patients did.

One reason for studying individual differences in the sense of presence is that the ability to experience presence in a mediated world can be a precondition to the effectiveness of cyber treatment. For instance, Wallach and her colleagues studied the effect of participants’ empathy, imagination, immersive tendency, dissociation tendencies, locus of control (Wallach et al. 2010) and anxiety/avoidance level (Wallach et al. 2009) on their sense of presence. Their goal was to identify the profile of the participant who could benefit from virtual reality exposure for fear of flight. They found a correlation between immersive tendency and the level of presence, as well as a negative correlation between avoidance and one dimension of presence, involvement/control.

Once it has been ascertained that there are individual differences in the way in which presence can be experienced in a virtual environment for cybertherapy, the next goal would be to set a critical level of presence under which the success of the therapy or its length would be dramatically affected. Investigations such as the ones considered in this paragraph should then be combined with those considered in the previous one, to check whether a different level of presence affects the success of the therapy and—in this case—what level of presence is acceptable to consider a patient as eligible for cybertherapy.

Presence assessment techniques in cybertherapy literature

The methods used to capture presence deserve special attention because the measurement tools contain underlying assumptions on the nature of the presence experience. It is interesting to examine which measures have been used in the cybertherapy literature and how they relate to the peculiarity of a mediated environment for psychological therapy. Specifically, presence has been conceived as an illusion, and evidence that the user is deceived into believing in the illusion of a virtual world as real are considered as indices of presence; this is the case when reality judgment is measured (Baños et al. 2000), as well as when behavioral reactions are recorded, such as ducking when an object is looming to the users (Held and Durlach 1992) or rotating the shoulders to pass through a tight door entrance (Lepecq et al. 2009). Alternatively, presence has been considered a choice of attending to either an alternative environment or as a consequence of attention allocation (Laarni et al. 2004), then it can be measured with secondary task reaction time (STRT). STRT is a continuous measure that assesses the level of attention a participant is giving a particular task by measuring the duration of time it takes for a participant to respond to either an audio and/or visual cue provided during a media or virtual experience (Basil 1994). Moreover, if presence is considered as the emotional involvement with the elements of the virtual environment, then physiological activation is measured via psychophysiological measures such as ECG (i.e., heart rate) or galvanic skin response (Sponselee et al. 2004). Finally, if scholars are interested not in measuring presence but in understanding it, the assessment tool will be probably qualitative in order to capture the configuration of the users’ sense of presence in the specific mediated environment for the user (Spagnolli and Gamberini 2005).

The presence assessment in cybertherapy does not seem to reflect this rich theoretical nuancing of the presence concept. The synopsis of all studies considered in our review (Table 1) shows that most often in cybertherapy literature, presence is measured through questionnaires (Table 2). Across the cybertherapy studies included in this analysis, the most frequently employed questionnaire is the PQ (Witmer and Singer 1998), comprised of 32 Likert-type items divided into four factors through principal-components factor analysis (i.e., control, sensory modality, distraction, and realism). Additionally, construct validity was established through cluster analysis. Witmer and Singer also provide internal consistency measures of reliability and report a Cronbach’s Alpha = .81. Further validation was undertaken and published in 2005 (Witmer et al. 2005) for versions 3.0 of the PQ. Another prevalent PQ is the SUS (Slater et al. 1994), which contains six items with Likert-type response options and focuses on a single dimension—spatial presence. Slater et al. did not report reliability or validity. However, in 2000 Usoh, Catena, Arman and Slater compared the SUS and PQ to assessment of virtual reality and physical reality scenarios (Usoh 2000). The results indicated that neither the SUS nor PQ demonstrated in significant differences between VR and physical reality and the authors concluded that the questionnaire is useful in measuring media users’ sense of ‘being in’ a virtual environment. The Igroup Presence Question (IPQ) was developed to measure physical presence (Schubert et al. 2001). The scale uses five-point Likert-type response options and is comprised of three factors—spatial presence, involvement, and realness. Validity was assessed in several studies and the results can be seen at the following URL: http://www.igroup.org/pq/ipq/factor.php. The immersive tendencies questionnaire (ITQ) was developed by Witmer and Singer (1998) and was developed simultaneously with the PQ. The difference between the two questionnaires is that the ITQ focuses on the ability to become immersed as a personality trait, while the PQ measures the degree to which individuals experience presence (or sense of being in) a virtual environment. The ITQ has 29 questions with Likert-type response options. There are two sub-dimensions: the tendency to become involved in activities and the tendency to maintain focus during activities. Witmer and Singer established the internal consistency of the ITQ through Cronbach’s Alpha = .75. Additionally, construct validity was established through cluster analysis. The ITC-SOPI (Sense of Presence Inventory) has 44 items with four factors (Sense of Physical Space, Engagement, Ecological Validity, and Negative Effects) (Lessiter et al. 2001). The questionnaire was designed to be a cross-media measure with the goal of encouraging different researchers and research labs to compare data and results. Reliability was assessed using Cronbach’s alpha (Sense of Physical Space = 0.94; Engagement = 0.89; Ecological Validity = 0.76; Negative Effects = 0.77). The presence and reality judgment questionnaire (PRJQ) (Baños et al. 2000) contains 18 items and has three factors (reality judgments, internal/external correspondence, and attention/absorption). Construct validity was determined through exploratory analysis (principal axis factoring). Cronbach’s alpha was employed to establish reliability (0.82 overall). Lastly, the temple presence inventory, or TPI (Lombard et al. 2009) was developed to measure the conceptualization of presence presented by (Lombard and Ditton 1997) and has then eight factors (spatial presence, parasocial interaction, passive social presence, active social presence, engagement, social richness, social realism, and perceptual realism). The authors provide a range of Cronbach’s Alpha values with Active Social Presence (α = .860) being the lowest to the highest Cronbach’s Alpha value (α = .919) for the Social Richness factor. The questionnaire has been applied to several media formats including video games, TV, and cinema presentations of film to establish content validity. Further, concurrent validity was established with intercorrelational analyses to compare subscales with other existing PQ. More details on psychometric characteristics of PQ were compiled by van Baren and IJsselsteijn (2004).

These measurement choices raise several issues. First of all, for an application domain where much of the effort is devoted to work on the meaning attributed by users to stimuli and situations, the use of qualitative methods to investigate the nature of the presence experience within the mediated environment is surprisingly rare [noticeable exception: (Belloni et al. 2007)]. This resonates with a predominance use of quantitative techniques in the health and clinical sector, because of the higher difficulty in assessing the quality of the knowledge produced using qualitative methods (Mays and Pope 2000), as well as to the lower appeal to commissioners and users of findings derived from a few case studies (Murphy et al. 1998). Nonetheless, also the use of questionnaires has inherent weaknesses, which have been also highlighted in the domain of presence studies (Bracken et al. 2008; Slater and Steed 2000) to overcome these weaknesses some researchers have used continuous measurement techniques allowing participants to rate their emotions and sensations of presence during the actual media or virtual experience (Robillard et al. 2003); others resort to behavioral indices or physiological activation (e.g., Sponselee et al. 2004), which do not require the participant to reflect on the experience during the cybertherapy treatment session nor to interrupt it. However, these cases are rare.

Second, among the PQ most commonly used in cybertherapy, the only one that was actually developed by a team of experts in cybertherapy is the PRJQ; however, the connection between the construct of reality judgment and mental health applications has not been explicitly articulated. Therefore, there might be specificities of cybertherapy applications that are not addressed by generic PQ. For instance, some items might be inadequate to measure the presence experience since their rating is due to other explanations: for instance, in (Bouchard et al. 2008) the PQ scores correlated negatively with anxiety, contrary to hypothesis, according to previous findings and to other presence measures (i.e., verbal measures) in the same study. The authors stated this was due to the fact that the PQ contained ‘a few items that may express users’ behavioral inhibition caused by fear’ (p. 385): in other words, some items could be not be conceptually considered as indicators of presence since the kind of environment and type of disease made it impossible for participants to rate those items high. Therefore, these questionnaires are used because they are already established tools in the study of presence and because they allow comparison across studies. But on the other hand it is important that authors are ready to identify their limitations when applied to cybertherapy environments. For instance, Bouchard, St-Jacques, Robillard and Renaud who have adopted the PQ in their study found it inadequate to actually capture the subjective experience of presence (Bouchard et al. 2008) and Juan and Dennis who adopted the SUS are not fully convinced that a participant after the experience is able to recall the experience itself (Juan and Joele 2011).

Discussion and conclusions

We have argued that cybertherapy is interconnected with the concept of presence. In cybertherapy, the mediated environment with its hardware and software is an integral part of the treatment and coincides with the intended outcome. Therefore, the concept of presence, defined as the sense of being in the mediated environment, is especially relevant in cybertherapy, in both immersive and non-immersive environments. More than in other application domains, the success of the mediated experience is instrumental to achieving the main goal of the application. It follows then that the concept of presence has been addressed in cybertherapy research as potentially useful as part of its internal validation, as reflected by the studies identified in our bibliographic search. We have examined these studies, trying to single out the role that presence can play in the validation of a cybertherapy treatment.

First, we found that presence is treated (a) as a sub-goal of the cybertherapy experience, indexing success in building the mediated environment hosting the treatment. As such, presence is a well suited to assessing internal validity of the cybertherapy. To this respect, we have highlighted that presence is not a direct consequence of the nature of the technical environment, especially in a field such as cybertherapy in which the environment has a deep meaning for some specific classes of users, i.e., the patients suffering from the disease targeted by the therapy. The sense of presence is then mediated by this meaning and by the factors that can affect this meaning.

Second, presence is also treated (b) as a construct that might correlate with other relevant constructs capturing the users’ experience during/after the treatment, including the treatment outcome. In particular, several studies have found a strict interdependence between presence and anxiety. If the relationship between the sense of presence and other psychological dimensions of the patients’ experience during the treatment were better elaborated on a theoretical basis, it could help establish construct validity for the cybertherapy. In doing this, it must be considered that presence might reach a level beyond which it cannot further increase, and this ceiling effect might undermine the bases of a correlation with other variables.

Third, presence has been treated (c) as a dimension subject to individual differences including differences due to the specific disease suffered by the patient, which might hamper the experience of certain sub-dimensions of presence or on the contrary might intensify the sense of presence experienced. This means that presence assessment concurs to establish the external validity of the treatment and is useful also to identify eligible patients for cybertherapy.

Finally, we have also considered the techniques adopted in these studies to assess presence, and noticed the prominent reliance on a small set of questionnaires developed outside the realm of cybertherapy. Questionnaires were found to be the most common technique to assess presence in the cybertherapy literature. They measure dimensions such as control, sensory modality, distraction, realism, spatial presence, involvement, realness reality judgment, social presence. We noticed that most of them have not been developed within this domain, but have been borrowed from the main field of virtual reality and media studies. The adoption of such questionnaires might result in a lack of sensitivity to the specificities of cybertherapy application such that some statements or attributes do not apply for reasons due to the specific disease addressed by the VE. While using these common PQ allows for the comparison of the study results with those of other studies, it is also useful to reflect on the way in which the disease addressed by the VE might affect the response to the questionnaire and which operationalizations of the concept of presence (see Sect. 3) can better fit the specific study goals. Also, a qualitative investigation on the nature of the subjective experience of presence in the mediated environment of the cybertherapy might unveil some of its specificities in this application domain and contribute to evaluate the achievement of some therapeutic goals. A mixed-method procedure, for instance, could be adopted (Hesse-Biber 2012). Also, it is important that the selection of the tool to capture presence fits the conceptual framework of the cybertherapy treatment.

Limitations

As will all studies, there are limitations to our examination of presence and cybertherapy. While we made every effort to be systematic in our creation of the sample, we did not conduct a pure Cochrane’s search. However, the current study and sample creation does meet the criteria for a systematic review. Additionally, the database search was conducted through 2011 and there may be additional, more recent studies which are not included in our sample.

Conclusion

In conclusion, inspired by the best practices, we have observed in the studies considered here, and by some findings about presence discussed above, some steps should be taken when using presence in cybertherapy validation. These steps create a short checklist:

  1. 1.

    Explicitly define presence at a conceptual level with reference to existing conceptualizations in the presence literature

  2. 2.

    Describe the actual contours of the mediated environment of cybertherapy and what it entails to be present in that environment (e.g., does it exclude real stimuli? Does it include the presence of the therapist?)

  3. 3.

    Check the consistency between the operationalization of presence in the measurement tool adopted and the conceptual definition of presence selected for the study

  4. 4.

    Outline the expected relationship between presence and other relevant psychological dimensions of the experience during cybertherapy treatment (e.g., anxiety), also taking into account the ceiling effect in presence measures

  5. 5.

    Consider whether critical individual differences in the target users might affect the way in which presence is experienced (e.g., immersive tendency, etc. …), especially, consider whether the disease is likely to undermine certain aspects of the presence experience, making some measurement techniques/subscales inadequate.

  6. 6.

    Consider including also other measures of presence than self-reported ones.

Addressing all items in the checklist while planning the study will improve the depth of the validation and help to avoid simplistic usages of the notion of presence or theoretical inconsistencies in the validation rationale.

    View author publications
